source.title: Gospel and Word of the Day - 13 December 2025

celebrations.name: Saint Lucy of Syracuse, Virgin and Martyr

readings.heading: A reading from the Book of Sirach
lines: Also there arose Elijah the prophet as fire,
And his word burned like a torch:
Who brought a famine upon them,
And by his zeal made them few in number.
By the word of the Lord he shut up the heaven:
Thrice did he thus bring down fire.
How was you glorified, O Elijah, in your wondrous deeds!
And who shall glory like to you?
Who was taken up in a tempest of fire,
In a chariot of fiery horses:
Who was recorded for reproofs in their seasons,
To pacify anger, before it brake forth into wrath;
To turn the heart of the father to the son,
And to restore the tribes of Jacob.
Blessed are those who saw you,
And those who have been beautified with love;
For we also shall surely live.

readings.heading: From the Gospel according to Matthew
lines: As they were coming down from the mountain, Jesus commanded them, saying,
“Don’t tell anyone what you saw, until the Son of Man has risen from the dead.”
His disciples asked him, saying, “Then why do the scribes say that Elijah must come first?”
Jesus answered them,
“Elijah indeed comes first, and will restore all things,
but I tell you that Elijah has come already, and they didn’t recognize him, but did to him whatever they wanted to. Even so the Son of Man will also suffer by them.”
Then the disciples understood that he spoke to them of John the Baptizer.

marginalia.text: Prophet figured as combustion: person and speech are the same fire.
Miracle as attrition; zeal reduces bodies, not merely arguments.
Cosmos obeys a sentence; the sky becomes a shutter. Fire is liturgical, repeated (“thrice”).
Exit is not death but ascent; theophany translated into transport.
Elijah kept on record as a timed instrument: reproof deployed to prevent rage’s ignition.
Restoration defined as reordering kinship and tribe; covenant repair is social, not private.
Beatitude attaches to witnesses; life is promised as continuity, not escape.
Commanded silence: revelation is embargoed until resurrection makes it legible.
Scribes frame expectation as sequence: Elijah as prerequisite.
Double claim: Elijah ‘will’ restore, yet ‘has’ come—fulfilled under misrecognition and violence.
Patterning: what was done to the forerunner prefigures what will be done to the Son; comprehension arrives late, after identification.

gospel.text: The transfiguration is sealed behind a temporal lock; disclosure awaits the interpretive key of rising.
Jesus concedes the restorative schema while asserting its paradoxical completion: Elijah arrived unrecognized, and covenant restoration proceeds through rejection.
John is named as the Elijah-function; the forerunner’s suffering is the template for the Messiah’s.

reading.text: Elijah is rendered as elemental force; speech acts scorch, not persuade.
Power is judicial: famine, shut heaven, descending fire—creation as responsive courtroom.
His removal intensifies his role: an absent prophet becomes an eschatological lever for turning hearts and reconstituting Israel.
The text ends with survivance: those who saw are blessed; the community claims future life by association with this prophetic economy.

commentary.synthesis: Sirach casts Elijah as fiery agent who restrains wrath and repairs the covenant order; Matthew relocates that Elijah-work into John, where ‘restoration’ is inaugurated not by acclaim but by misrecognition, and the same pattern is slated to fall on the Son after the mountain’s unveiled glory.
commentary.excursus:
Sirach gives you Elijah as a combustive principle: not merely a man with miracles, but a walking theophany whose “word” is pyroclastic—speech as flame, rhetoric as judgment. The text admires him the way iron admires the magnet: with fear disguised as encomium. The famine and the fire are not “power demonstrations” but covenantal enforcement, i.e., God’s politics executed through a zealot. Sirach also does something sly: Elijah is both catastrophe and katechon. He shuts heaven (de-creation), yet he’s “recorded” to pacify anger before it becomes wrath (re-creation). That’s a priestly function attributed to a prophet: he is filed away like an apotropaic document to be produced “in their seasons.” The famous “turn the heart of the father to the son” is not sentimental therapy; it’s civilizational re-binding, the repair of generational discontinuity that makes a people governable again. “Restore the tribes of Jacob” is national, not merely spiritual: a promise of reconstitution after dispersion. Sirach’s last line—“we also shall surely live”—rides on this: Elijah guarantees futurity.

Matthew, coming down from the mountain, immediately plays the esoteric card: secrecy until resurrection. Transfiguration is too raw to circulate without the interpretive key of the cross; otherwise you get a triumphalist cult with no cruciform grammar. Then the disciples ask the scribal question, and Jesus answers with a double register: Elijah “will” come and Elijah “has” come. That’s not confusion; it’s a deliberate temporal folding. On the surface, it identifies John as Elijah. Underneath, it preserves an unspent remainder of the Elijah-expectation: the typology is satisfied, yet the archetype is not exhausted. The kingdom runs on recapitulations.

The decisive sting is “they didn’t recognize him.” Sirach’s Elijah is unmistakable—fire, horses, tempest, cosmic theater. Matthew’s Elijah is misrecognized, handled like disposable nuisance, “whatever they wanted.” That’s the inversion: in the new economy, the Elijah-function hides in the unglamorous and gets crushed by institutions. Recognition becomes a moral test: the powerful can only recognize power. Hence John-as-Elijah is an anti-miracle: not chariot-fire but prison and beheading, and precisely there the prophetic office is fulfilled.
